page.title: 01The Isle of May
page.content: The Isle of May is the outermost of the several rocky islands in the Firth of Forth. The island lies 8km (5miles) south-east of the Fife coast and 17km (11miles) north of the East Lothian coast. The island is 550m wide and 1600km long, its axis runs north-west - south-east and it covers an area of 57ha a tenth of which is bare rock. The Isle is owned by the Northern Lighthose Board and has been designated as a National Nature Reserve because of the large numbers and varieties of birds which visit the island. A small section at the southern end of the Isle is not within this "Domesday" square (it is in square 03640696), however, it is felt that the island should be dealt with as a single entity. The text for both squares will therefore be the same.
